1.text: Dost thou draw leviathan with an angle? And with a rope thou lettest down—his tongue?

2.text: Dost thou put a reed in his nose? And with a thorn pierce his jaw?

3.text: Doth he multiply unto thee supplications? Doth he speak unto thee tender things?

4.text: Doth he make a covenant with thee? Dost thou take him for a servant age-during?

5.text: Dost thou play with him as a bird? And dost thou bind him for thy damsels?

6.text: (Feast upon him do companions, They divide him among the merchants!)

7.text: Dost thou fill with barbed irons his skin? And with fish-spears his head?

8.text: Place on him thy hand, Remember the battle—do not add!

9.text: Lo, the hope of him is found a liar, Also at his appearance is not one cast down?

10.text: None so fierce that he doth awake him, And who is he before Me stationeth himself?

11.text: Who hath brought before Me and I repay? Under the whole heavens it is mine.

12.text: I do not keep silent concerning his parts, And the matter of might, And the grace of his arrangement.

13.text: Who hath uncovered the face of his clothing? Within his double bridle who doth enter?

14.text: The doors of his face who hath opened? Round about his teeth are terrible.

15.text: A pride—strong ones of shields, Shut up—a close seal.

16.text: One unto another they draw nigh, And air doth not enter between them.

17.text: One unto another they adhere, They stick together and are not separated.

18.text: His sneezings cause light to shine, And his eyes are as the eyelids of the dawn.

19.text: Out of his mouth do flames go, sparks of fire escape.

20.text: Out of his nostrils goeth forth smoke, As a blown pot and reeds.

21.text: His breath setteth coals on fire, And a flame from his mouth goeth forth.

22.text: In his neck lodge doth strength, And before him doth grief exult.

23.text: The flakes of his flesh have adhered—Firm upon him—it is not moved.

24.text: His heart is firm as a stone, Yea, firm as the lower piece.

25.text: From his rising are the mighty afraid, From breakings they keep themselves free.

26.text: The sword of his overtaker standeth not, Spear—dart—and lance.

27.text: He reckoneth iron as straw, brass as rotten wood.

28.text: The son of the bow doth not cause him to flee, Turned by him into stubble are stones of the sling.

29.text: As stubble have darts been reckoned, And he laugheth at the shaking of a javelin.

30.text: Under him are sharp points of clay, He spreadeth gold on the mire.

31.text: He causeth to boil as a pot the deep, The sea he maketh as a pot of ointment.

32.text: After him he causeth a path to shine, One thinketh the deep to be hoary.

33.text: There is not on the earth his like, That is made without terror.

34.text: Every high thing he doth see, He is king over all sons of pride.
